Madeline and the Black Velvet band recorded Black Velvet in between national and international tour dates. Inspired by Neil YoungÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s producer David BriggsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ work, Madeline followed the strategy of On The Beach and TonightÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the Night Ã¢â‚¬â€œ recording whenever and wherever they could find a couple of microphones, and focusing on capturing the energy of a live show. Black Velvet sounds like an Arthur Russel record one minute, all bedroom pop and private crooning, while turning around and twisting into dark Jefferson Airplane-esque psychedelia the next. MadelineÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s signature Karen Carpenter/Neko Case meets The Carter Family southern ballads still make an appearance with lyrics about everything from Johnny CashÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s career as heavenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s angel barber to the joy of talking cops out of DUIs. Black Velvet is one of those albums you can see while you hear; a mental music video for every song. Madeline has finally and fearlessly let her mind, mouth and heart open far enough for everyone to get a good look and the results are nothing short of thrilling
